meanings.def: something that you allow or do, or allow somebody to have, in order to end an argument or to make a situation less difficult
examples: The firm will be forced to make concessions if it wants to avoid a strike.
to win a concession from somebody
She made no concession to his age; she expected him to work as hard as she did.
The company will be forced to make concessions to the union.
The pressure group has won a number of concessions on environmental policy.
They made no concessions to his disability.
They remained unwilling to make any substantial concessions.

meanings.def: the act of giving something or allowing something; the act of conceding
examples: the concession of university status to some colleges
Clinton’s concession speech (= when she admitted that she had lost the election)
Military support was offered in return for the concession of territory.

meanings.def: a reduction in an amount of money that has to be paid; a ticket that is sold at a reduced price to a particular group of people
examples: They may grant tax concessions to encourage foreign investors.
Tickets are £3; there is a £1 concession for students.
Travel concessions are available to older people.

meanings.def: a right or an advantage that is given to a group of people, an organization, etc., especially by a government or an employer
examples: The Bolivian government has granted logging concessions covering 22 million hectares.
The company has just won a mining concession in the north of the country.

meanings.def: the right to sell something in a particular place; the place where you sell it, sometimes an area that is part of a larger building or store
examples: the burger concessions at the stadium
(especially US English) They went to the concession stand to get a hot dog.
